afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:27): I put it in quotes, because, I HATES it.
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:27): it does weird things.
f4287329f092a30466e5e999856697cd (02:28): attention developers: /bin/sh != /bin/bash
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:28): it's become the emacs of shells, just like vim is the emacs of vi's.
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:28): the-decider is a lover of the tcsh.
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:28): nah, I don't love it -- I just don't want to re-write my .cshrc or anything ;)
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:28): kewl openbsd supports ultrasparc iii
d0670804b0a4d1e7e95d5f8b7077b1ca (02:29): Is it possible to munt a windows VFAT partition from solaris ?
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (02:30): yes, mount -F pcfs
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:30): SolMan: mount -F pcfs /dev/blah /mntpoint
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:30): silly solaris VFS interface
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:31): don't be like linux, pretty please
d0670804b0a4d1e7e95d5f8b7077b1ca (02:32): elektronkind, thank you! BTW, for general knowledge - in case it was an ntfs partition - what than? was it possible?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:33): there's a way to mount NTFS in solaris, but it's not as straight-forward.
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:33): it requires a 3rd party (open source) package, iirc
5a2f1c3667886a3c922e7ad2f06ca9b8 (02:33): http://sourceforge.net/projects/mount-ntfs/ is the link i think
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:33): http://blogs.sun.com/pradhap/entry/mounting_ntfs_partition_in_solaris
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:34): yeah, either of those urls

d0670804b0a4d1e7e95d5f8b7077b1ca (02:35): elektronkind, and regarding linux ext3/ext2 ?  I think that I saw somewhere that it is also no straightforward; you also need to install some package if i am not wrong
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:37): SolMan: http://www.genunix.org/distributions/belenix_site/belenix_home.html
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:37): see the second entry down
d0670804b0a4d1e7e95d5f8b7077b1ca (02:38): elektronkind, thnks again; reading...

b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:38): aka solaris packages
5a2f1c3667886a3c922e7ad2f06ca9b8 (02:39): System V Release 4
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:39): installed with the pkgadd command, for example
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:39): supertux op solaris nice ;-)
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:40): anyone have a *new* T1000 here?
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:40): the sun ads seem to say the new one has dual power supplies
778d97eab00032b3f494f2988d83c295 (02:40): anyone know if it's possible to have two desktops on a dell latitude d810 with nexenta?
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:41): but the specs only mention 1 power supply :/
778d97eab00032b3f494f2988d83c295 (02:41): I just plugged in the external monitor and it seems to display the same image on both screens at 1400x1200
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:41): hey, why would I get this error when doing useradd -m user?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:42): UX: useradd: ERROR: Unable to create the home directory: Operation not applicable.
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:43): agliodbs: run: svcadm disable autofs
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:43): and then try to remake your user
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:43): userdel user; useradd -m user
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:44): elektronkind: hmmm ... what is autofs used for?

b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:45): autofs is used for auto matically mounting a remote thing over NFS (such as a user's home directory) automatically when an attempt is make to access that thingy
0c5117cbac07829b6abdb4a8565d658e (02:45): agliodbs:  it's used for mount points like /net and /export/home
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:45): in the old days it was called automounter
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:45): ok, now I have a Solaris hacker question ...
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:46): moazamraja, you're sure? becuase the handbook only shows one
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:46): WOULD YOU LIKE TO PLAY A GAME?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:46): I'm trying to fix PostgreSQL compilations so that it picks the right fsync method for Solaris
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:47): fsync method?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:47): yeah, the data files need to be periodically synced to prevent data loss
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:47): is that like, only fsync before the last week of the month?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:48): does the catholic church approve of the fsync method?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:48): heh.  Is the Pope ANSI-compliant?  Does MySQL shit in the woods?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:48): seriously though, ah, you mean how often it syncs the data?
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:48): hmm, i guess it only has 1 power supply :(
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:48): yeah
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:48): moazamraja, but why not go for the t2000 instead?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:49): agliodbs: shouldn't that be left up to the underlying fs?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:49): elektronkind: not how often, which kernel call it uses
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:49): elektronkind: not if you want to be ACID-compliant, no
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:49): agliodbs: what are your fsync options?
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:49): or was it sleep(60)
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:49): so quaint.
75dd2071a30b7c94d9361f05f06d524c (02:49): wow. that's quite the hack.
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:50): fsync, fdatasync, o_sync, o_datasync
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:50): hspaans: it's almost DOUBLE the price?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:50): o_datasync is the fastest for Solaris/UFS
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:50): actually, it was more complicated -- you could set an option for how long you wanted the sleep period to be.
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:50): but for some reason postgresql doesn't seem to be picking up the right sync method from the OS on compilation
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:50): those were the days.
83c40fe33385c596f672ec2df316004b (02:50): and when you are buying more than just 1-2 T1000/T2000s, the expense is ridiculously high
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:51): agliodbs: well the compiler doesn't choose that kind of thing
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:51): no, there's a script in PostgreSQL in the headers that checks what's supported
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:52): and for some reason it thinks that solaris supports only "fsync"
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:52): agliodbs: I'm not a pg user, but I imagine fsync is the default, and the others are more site-specific.
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:52): anyone remember the j00z  you had to do to install Ultrix 4.3 on a non-DEC SCSI disk? ;)
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:52): elektronkind: well, there's a priority order
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:52): we only drop down to fsync if nothing else is supported
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:53): agliodbs: this is solaris 10?
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:53): but solaris supports all of those ... just for some reason we can't get that data out of the OS headers durning compilation
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:53): elektronkind: and nevada, too
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:53): AFAIK
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:53): agliodbs: you might want to look at config.log to see why it's not detecting fdatasync and the others, which are valid on solaris 109
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:53): agliodbs: if you want safe, use whatever default they give you.  But I'd check the postgres faq, since they probably outline tradeoffs incurred using them.
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:53): moazamraja, sorry bt t1000 vs t2000 is like x2100 vs x4100
ee0a31ca605f8d965931c8adb3ac129e (02:54): the-decider: I'm one of the PostgreSQL developers
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:54): moazamraja, but yes it depends on what you want and need
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:54): agliodbs, thank you for postgresql in that case ;-)
afa160103c8346fc19df3e8f25be124b (02:54): ok, funny rant then, why did you guys get rid of the timetravel functionality, it was so cool. ;)
